article.headline: Teslaâs stock soars to 4th-straight record as Wall Streetâs biggest bear raises price target
article.body: Shares of Tesla Inc. charged higher to a fourth-straight record close Monday, after even the most bearish analyst on Wall Street analyst lifted his price target following the electric vehicle makerâs blowout deliveries results. Tesla rival Nio Inc.âs stock NIO, +0.14% Â also soared, in the wake of the China-based EV makerâs upbeat June sales report. Meanwhile, among other EV makers, shares of Workhorse Group Inc. WKHS, +12.62% Â pulled back after a record 11-day win streak and Nikola Corp. NKLA, -1.36% Â was headed for a fourth straight loss. Teslaâs stock TSLA, +1.89% Â shot up a record $162.92, or 13.5%, to $1,371.58. The stock has soared 42.9% over the past five days, the last four of which were record closing prices. Analyst Ryan Brinkman at JPMorgan raised his stock price target by 7.3% to $295, but that was still 78.5% below current prices. Brinkmanâs target remained the lowest of the 32 analysts surveyed by FactSet. The price target increase follows Teslaâs report Thursday that it delivered 90,650 vehicles in the second quarter, well above expectations of 72,000. Donât miss: Tesla stock rockets higher as quarterly sales crush expectations. See related: Some workers complain Tesla has threatened firings if they donât return to work. Brinkman said that the deliveries data led Chief Executive Elon Musk to imply Teslaâs second-quarter report, due out on or about July 22, could produce a surprise break-even result. But he cautioned investors that any âsubstantially better resultsâ could include items that are âone-time or somewhat one-time in nature,â such as zero-emission regulatory credit sales or the release of deferred revenue associated with autonomous driving features. Brinkman reiterated the underweight rating heâs had on Tesla for at least the last three years, citing âlofty valuationâ coupled with âhigh investor expectations and high execution risk.â âOur underweight rating considers notable investment positives, including a highly differentiated business model, appealing product portfolio, and leading-edge technology, which we believe are more than offset by above-average execution risk and valuation that seems to be pricing in a lot,â Brinkman wrote in a note to clients. Of the 32 analysts surveyed by FactSet, 12 have the equivalent of sell ratings on Tesla, while 11 have the equivalent of hold and 9 have the equivalent of buy. The average price target is $774.98, or 43.5% below current prices. FactSet Nioâs stock ran up 22.7% to $11.51, to also record a fifth straight gain. That was the stockâs second-highest close since going public on Sept. 12, 2018. The record close of $11.60 was reached on Sept. 13, 2018. The stock has rocketed 66.8% during its current win streak. Nio reported last week that June sales rose 179% from a year ago to 3,740 EVs. That consisted of 2,476 ES6 model EVs, which are Nioâs small SUVs, and 1,264 ES8 EVs. That took second-quarter sales to 10,331 vehicles, up 191% from a year ago. Separately, DigiTimes reported Monday that Nio raised funds totaling $1.97 billion in the first half of 2020, and has acquired a factory in central China as it looks to expand its production capacity to 4,500 to 5,000 EVs a month from the current rate of 4,000. FactSet, MarketWatch Not all EV makers enjoyed gains Monday, as Workhorseâs stockÂ tumbled 15.8% to $17.61, the first decline in 12 sessions. The stock had rocketed more than fivefold (up 406%) during its record 11-day win streak through Thursday, which was supported by the announcement last week of a $70 million securities purchase agreement from an institutional investor. Nikolaâs stockÂ slumped 14.5% to $48.92 on Monday. It has shed 38.1% amid a four-day losing streak, and has tumbled 38.6% since the June 9 record close of $79.73. JPMorganâs Paul Coster had started coverage of the battery-electric and hydrogen-electric vehicle maker late last month with a neutral rating, saying the company was poised to disrupt the transportation industry. Despite the pullbacks, Workhorseâs stock was still up nearly sixfold (up 479.3%) year to date and Nikola shares were up nearly fivefold ( up 374.0%). Teslaâs stock has more than tripled (up 227.9%) this year and Nioâs stock has nearly tripled (up 186.3%), while the S&P 500 index SPX, +0.87% Â has slipped 1.6%.
